questions.question_text: During a routine check, a systems administrator discovers that a userâ€™s PC is running slowly and CPU utilization is at 100%. Further investigation shows a large amount of resource usage. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the high resource usage?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Botnet attack

A botnet attack is the most likely cause of high CPU utilization, especially when it's accompanied by slow performance. In a botnet attack, a malicious actor controls multiple compromised devices, including the affected PC, to perform tasks like spamming, DDoS attacks, or mining cryptocurrency. These activities consume significant system resources, leading to high CPU usage.

B
Signs that a device may be part of a botnet include slow performance, unusual network activity, frequent crashes, unexpected pop-ups or ads, and high CPU or memory usage without an obvious cause.

choices.A: Make office attendance mandatory for one day per week so that updates can be installed.
choices.B: Ask users to ensure that they run updates on devices and reboot computers on a regular basis.
choices.C: Push updates out via VPN on a weekly basis in a staggered manner so that the network is not affected.
choices.D: Configure cloud-based endpoint management software to automatically manage computer updates.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Configure cloud-based endpoint management software to automatically manage computer updates.

This option provides the most effective and efficient solution for managing updates across a geographically dispersed workforce. Cloud-based endpoint management software can:

Automate updates: Schedule and deploy updates automatically, ensuring devices are always up-to-date.
Remote management: Allow administrators to manage devices remotely, including troubleshooting and configuration changes.
Security: Enforce security policies and protect devices from threats.
Flexibility: Adapt to the varying needs of different users and devices.

GG

Selected Answer: D
I assume this is supposed to say "several national offices that staff can go to for technical support"

Anyways if you want to remotely push device updates across a wide area over the internet you'd use a cloud based endpoint management software and the rest of the options are nonsense.

comments.content: If you want a good example, look up Microsoft Intune.

discussion.content: Question does not make any sense

questions.question_text: A technician needs to recommend a way to keep company devices for field and home-based staff up to date. The users live in various places across the country and the company has several national offices that stair can go no for technical support. Which of the following methods is most appropriate for the users?

discussion.content:
B. cleanmgr.exe
Cleanmgr.exe is the Disk Cleanup tool, which is designed to free up disk space by removing unnecessary files. It can identify and remove various types of temporary files, system files, and other junk files that may be taking up space on the hard drive.

This is the most appropriate tool for addressing the issue of low disk space caused by leftover upgrade files.

Google Gemini

questions.question_text: A users Windows desktop has low disk space. A technician thinks some upgrade files were never removed. Which of the following tools should me technician use to correct the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
After verifying the malware, quarantining would be the next step in malware removal process.
Comptia Exam Objectives for malware removal.
1. Investigate and verify malware symptoms
2.Quarantine infected systems
3.Disable System Restore in Windows
4.Remediate infected systems
 a. Update anti-malware software
 b.Scanning and removal techniques (e.g., safe mode, preinstallation environment)
5.Schedule scans and run updates
6.Enable System Restore and create a restore point in Windows
7. Educate the end user

Selected Answer: C
The answer is C because generally, quarantining a system is the first thing you do in malware removal. Then comes disabling system restore, then scan and remove the malware, and then schedule automated malware scans.

Selected Answer: C
PC is infected with ransomware, and malware scan will not prevent access to compromised information and data. Best thing to do is save what you can and isolate from the network.
Whenever system is suffering from Ransomware it should be isolated from network

Selected Answer: C
Always. Quarantine. First.

Selected Answer: C
Not great question but answer is C.

Selected Answer: C
Quarantine the unit to not affect other users if the ransomware can affect the network. It was not recoverable even if you paid them and some ransomware keys were exposed online.
Quarantine it guys, don't want it to spread like wildfire.

questions.question_text: A user calls the help desk to report that none of the files on a PC will open. The user also indicates a program on the desktop is requesting payment in exchange for file access. A technician verifies the user's PC is infected with ransomware. Which of the following should the technician do FIRST?

choices.E: Removing dust from the ventilation fans
choices.B: Disconnecting the computer from the power source
choices.C: Placing the PSU in an antistatic bag

comments.content: Hahaha ive seen your comments a few times in some of these questions and they crack me up with how you realize things. They're correct and informational, but they just make me laugh
Yes you are correct actually, A and B
I think they key here is "prior to opening the computer". placing the psu in an antistatic bag would require opening the PC.
no way. It is C and E

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
The CPU is not a hot-swappable component, so you would need to remove the power first. Then, just use an ESD strap to protect the equipment from Electrostatic discharge. Therefore, A and B are the best answers.

Selected Answer: AB
You protect against ESD with the wrist strap and protect the components (and yourself) by disconnecting from the power because a CPU is not a hot swappable piec of equipment

Selected Answer: AF
An Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) strap helps to prevent static electricity from building up on the technician's body and potentially damaging sensitive electronic components inside the computer. Using an ESD strap ensures that any static charge is safely discharged to ground, protecting the internal components from electrostatic damage.
Grounding equipment, including the computer and work surface, helps to dissipate any static electricity and prevents electrostatic discharge from damaging internal components. Ensuring that the equipment is properly grounded provides an additional layer of protection against ESD during the component replacement process.

Utilizing an ESD strap (option A) and ensuring equipment is grounded (option F) are the best safety procedures to protect internal components during the processor replacement process.

Selected Answer: AB
Use an ESD strap & unplug the computer from power? I don't know....better go ask chatgpt, he'll know what to do.

Selected Answer: AF
You'll need to protect computer from ESD. Computer must be grounded!

Would it not be A & F? The question is asking to protect the components in the computer. So if the components are grounded and using EDS strap, it will prevent the components from being damaged? Correct me if I am wrong please.

Selected Answer: AC
A. Utilizing an ESD strap and C. Placing the PSU in an antistatic bag are the best safety procedures to protect the internal components in the PC.

An ESD (Electrostatic Discharge) strap helps to prevent damage to sensitive electronic components by grounding the technician, thereby preventing any static electricity discharge. Placing the Power Supply Unit (PSU) in an antistatic bag can also protect it from electrostatic discharge during the replacement process.

Disconnecting the computer from the power source is also important to prevent electrical shocks, but it will not protect the internal components from ESD. Ensuring proper ventilation and removing dust from the ventilation fans are important for maintaining the computer's cooling system but do not protect the internal components during a processor replacement. Ensuring equipment is grounded is also important but may not be sufficient to protect against ESD.

comments.content: "Prior to opening the computer" is the key phrase here. You can't put a PSU in the antistatic bag prior to opening the computer.

questions.question_text: A technician is replacing the processor in a desktop computer. Prior to opening the computer, the technician wants to ensure the internal components are protected. Which of the following safety procedures would BEST protect the components in the PC? (Choose two.)
